# S6. Proof of Theorem 1 

Theorem 1 follows from an extension of Theorem 4.1 from (Chernozhukov et al., 2018), and Theorems 3.3 and 3.6 from (Eberts and Steinwart, 2013). This section extends Theorem 4.1 from (Chernozhukov et al., 2018) to the case of a vector treatment variable, and then verifies that Assumptions A1-A6 satisfy the necessary conditions to apply these results.

## S6.1 Proof of DML with partially linear model

In this section we extend Theorem 4.1 from (Chernozhukov et al., 2018), which analyzes the partially linear model with a scalar treatment, to a vector treatment. The extension essentially follows the proof of Theorem 4.1 from (Chernozhukov et al., 2018) with slight changes.

We use "DML2", which is Definition 3.2 from Chernozhukov et al. (2018), where rather than aggregating K different estimates from K different folds, cross-fitting on the K folds is performed followed by estimation of $\boldsymbol{\beta}_{0}$ using the combined cross-fitted estimates.

The assumed model is:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{Y} & =\mathbf{X} \boldsymbol{\beta}+g_{0}(\mathbf{S})+\mathbf{U} \\
\mathbf{X}_{j} & =m_{0 j}(\mathbf{S})+\mathbf{V}_{j}
\end{aligned}
$$

with notation and definitions as in the main paper. Nuisance parameters and estimates $\eta$ are assumed to be in $T$, a convex subset of some normed vector space.

The "practical" DSR estimator uses the score function:

$$
\psi(\mathbf{W} ; \boldsymbol{\beta}, \eta):=\left\{Y-g(\mathbf{S})-\mathbf{X}^{T} \boldsymbol{\beta}\right\}(\mathbf{X}-m(\mathbf{S}))
$$

However, for theory, we focus on the score function:

$$
\psi(\mathbf{W} ; \boldsymbol{\beta}, \eta):=\left\{Y-h(\mathbf{S})-(\mathbf{X}-m(\mathbf{S}))^{T} \boldsymbol{\beta}\right\}(\mathbf{X}-m(\mathbf{S}))
$$

Assumption 1 consists of those of Assumption 4.1 from Chernozhukov et al. (2018) but expanded to encompass the case $p>1$, the length of $\boldsymbol{\beta}_{0}$, and with some other slight changes for theoretical convenience. Let $\left\{\delta_{n}\right\}$ and $\left\{\Delta_{n}\right\}$ be sequences of positive constants converging

to 0 . Let $c, C$, and $q$ be fixed strictly positive constants such that $q>4$, and let $K \geqslant 2$ be a fixed integer. For any $\eta=\left(\ell_{1}, \ell_{2}, \ldots, \ell_{m}\right)$ for any positive integer $m$ such that $\ell_{1}, \ldots, \ell_{m}$ are functions mapping $\mathcal{S}$ to $\mathbb{R}$, denote $\|\eta\|_{P, q}=\max _{1, \ldots, m}\left\{\left\|\ell_{1}\right\|_{P, q}, \ldots,\left\|\ell_{m}\right\|_{P, q}\right\}$.

Assumption 1 (Regularity Conditions for partially linear regression model): Let $\mathcal{P}$ be the collection of probability laws $P$ for $\mathbf{W}=(Y, \mathbf{X}, \mathbf{S})$ such that
a) Model (11) holds,
b) $\left\|V_{1}\right\|_{P, q}, \ldots,\left\|V_{p}\right\|_{P, q} \leqslant C$ and $\left\|\boldsymbol{\beta}_{0}\right\|_{\infty} \leqslant C$,
c) The eigenvalues of the matrix $E\left[U^{2} \mathbf{V} \mathbf{V}^{T}\right]$ are greater than or equal to $c^{2}$ and the matrix $E\left[\mathbf{V V}^{T}\right]$ has singular values at least $c$ and no greater than $C$,
d) $\left\|E\left[U^{2}|\mathbf{S}]\|_{P, \infty} \leqslant C\right.\right.$ and $\left\|E\left[V_{j}^{2}|\mathbf{S}]\|_{P, \infty} \leqslant C\right.$ for $j=1, \ldots, p$,
e) Given a random subset $I$ of $[n]$ of size $n / K$, the nuisance parameter estimator $\widehat{\eta}_{0}=$ $\widehat{\eta}_{0}\left(\left(\mathbf{W}_{i}\right)_{i \in I^{C}}\right)$ obey the following conditions for all $n / K \geqslant 1$ : with $P$-probability no less than $1-\Delta_{n}$,

$$
\left\|\widehat{\eta}_{0}-\eta_{0}\right\|_{P, \infty} \leqslant C,\left\|\widehat{\eta}_{0}-\eta_{0}\right\|_{P, 2} \leqslant \delta_{n}
$$

and for the score $\psi$ in (13), where $\widehat{\eta}=\left(\widehat{\ell}_{0}, \widehat{m}_{10}, \ldots, \widehat{m}_{p 0}\right)$,

$$
\left\|\widehat{m}_{j 0}-m_{j 0}\right\|_{P, 2} \times\left(\left\|\widehat{m}_{j 0}-m_{j 0}\right\|_{P, 2}+\left\|\widehat{\ell}_{0}-\ell_{0}\right\|_{P, 2}\right) \leqslant \delta_{n} n^{-1 / 2} \text { for } j=1, \ldots, p
$$

The following lemma is Theorem 4.1 from Chernozhukov et al. (2018) but expanded to the case $p>1$.

Lemma 1 (DML inference in the partially linear regression model with $p>1$ ): Suppose that Assumption 1 holds. Then the DML2 estimator constructed in Definition 3.2 of Chernozhukov et al. (2018) using the score (13) obeys

$$
\boldsymbol{\Sigma}^{-1 / 2} \sqrt{n}\left(\widehat{\boldsymbol{\beta}}_{0}-\boldsymbol{\beta}_{0}\right) \xrightarrow{P} N\left(\mathbf{0}, \mathbf{I}_{p}\right)
$$

uniformly over $P \in \mathcal{P}$, where $\boldsymbol{\Sigma}=\left[E\left(\mathbf{V} \mathbf{V}^{T}\right)\right]^{-1} E\left(U^{2} \mathbf{V} \mathbf{V}^{T}\right)\left[E\left(\mathbf{V} \mathbf{V}^{T}\right)\right]^{-1}$. The result continues to hold if $\boldsymbol{\Sigma}$ is replaced by $\widehat{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}$ from Theorem 3.2 from Chernozhukov et al. (2018).

The proof for Lemma 1 follows the proof of Theorem 4.1 in Chernozhukov et al. (2018) closely, only needing to add steps to deal with the vector-valued $\psi$ and matrix-valued $\psi^{a}$, and changing some assumptions slightly for convenience. The proof verifies Assumptions 3.1 and 3.2 from Chernozhukov et al. (2018), from which the conclusion of Lemma 1 follows from Theorems 3.1 and 3.2 from Chernozhukov et al. (2018).

Proof. [Proof of Lemma 1] Observe that the score (13) is linear in $\boldsymbol{\beta}$ :

$$
\begin{aligned}
\psi(\mathbf{W} ; \boldsymbol{\beta}, \eta) & =\left\{Y-\ell(\mathbf{S})-(\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{m}(\mathbf{S}))^{T} \boldsymbol{\beta}\right\}(\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{m}(\mathbf{S}))=\psi^{a}(\mathbf{W} ; \eta) \boldsymbol{\beta}+\psi^{b}(\mathbf{W} ; \eta) \\
\psi^{a}(\mathbf{W} ; \eta) & =-(\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{m}(\mathbf{S}))(\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{m}(\mathbf{S}))^{T}, \quad \psi^{b}(\mathbf{W} ; \eta)=(Y-\ell(\mathbf{S}))(\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{m}(\mathbf{S}))
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore, it is sufficient to verify Assumptions 3.1 and 3.2 from Chernozhukov et al. (2018). Let $\mathcal{T}_{n}$ be the set of all $\eta=\left(\ell, m_{1}, \ldots, m_{p}\right)$ consisting of $P$-square-integrable functions $\ell, m_{1}, \ldots, m_{p}$ such that

$$
\begin{gathered}
\left\|\widehat{\eta}_{0}-\eta_{0}\right\|_{P, q} \leqslant C,\left\|\widehat{\eta}_{0}-\eta_{0}\right\|_{P, 2} \leqslant \delta_{n} \\
\left\|\widehat{m}_{j 0}-m_{j 0}\right\|_{P, 2} \times\left(\left\|\widehat{m}_{j 0}-m_{j 0}\right\|_{P, 2}+\left\|\widehat{\ell}_{0}-\ell_{0}\right\|_{P, 2}\right) \leqslant \delta_{n} n^{-1 / 2}
\end{gathered}
$$

We replace the constant $q$ and the sequence $\left\{\delta_{n}\right\}$ in Assumptions 3.1 and 3.2 from Chernozhukov et al. (2018) by $q / 2$ and $\left\{\delta_{n}^{\prime}\right\}$, with $\delta_{n}^{\prime}=\left(2 p^{2} C+\sqrt{C} p+\sqrt{p C}+p C+p C \sqrt{p C}+\right.$ $\left.\sqrt{p} p C^{2}+4 \sqrt{p}\right)\left(\delta_{n} \vee n^{-[(1-4 / q) \wedge(1 / 2)]}\right)$ for all $n$. As in Chernozhukov et al. (2018), we use five steps.

Step 1. Verify Neyman orthogonality. Note that $E\left[\psi\left(\mathbf{W} ; \boldsymbol{\beta}_{0}, \eta_{0}\right)\right]=0$ by the definitions of $\boldsymbol{\beta}_{0}, \eta_{0}$. For any $\eta \in \mathcal{T}_{n}$, the Gateaux derivative in the direction $\eta-\eta_{0}$ is given by, for $r=0$, (see derivation in Step 5):

$$
\begin{aligned}
\partial_{\eta} E\left[\psi\left(\mathbf{W} ; \boldsymbol{\beta}_{0}, \eta_{0}\right)\right]\left[\eta-\eta_{0}\right] & =-E\left[\left(Y-\ell_{0}(\mathbf{S})\right)\left(\mathbf{m}(\mathbf{S})-\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})\right)\right]-E\left[\left(\ell(\mathbf{S})-\ell_{0}(\mathbf{S})\right)\left(\mathbf{D}-\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})\right)\right] \\
& +E\left[\left(\mathbf{D}-\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})\right)\left(\mathbf{m}(\mathbf{S})-\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})\right)^{T} \boldsymbol{\beta}_{0}\right] \\
& +E\left[\left(\mathbf{m}(\mathbf{S})-\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})\right)\left(\mathbf{D}-\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})\right)^{T} \boldsymbol{\beta}_{0}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

By the law of iterated expectation, and since $\mathbf{V}=\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})$ and $U=Y-\ell_{0}(\mathbf{S})$ :

$$
\begin{aligned}
\partial_{\eta} E\left[\psi\left(\mathbf{W} ; \boldsymbol{\beta}_{0}, \eta_{0}\right)\right]\left[\eta-\eta_{0}\right] & =E\left\{E\left[U \times\left(\mathbf{m}(\mathbf{S})-\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})\right) \mid \mathbf{X}, \mathbf{S}\right]\right\} \\
& -E\left\{E\left[\left(\ell(\mathbf{S})-\ell_{0}(\mathbf{S})\right) \mathbf{V} \mid \mathbf{S}\right]\right\} \\
& +E\left\{E\left[\left(\mathbf{m}(\mathbf{S})-\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})\right) \mathbf{V}^{T} \boldsymbol{\beta}_{0} \mid \mathbf{S}\right]\right\} \\
& +E\left\{E\left[\mathbf{V}\left(\mathbf{m}(\mathbf{S})-\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})\right)^{T} \boldsymbol{\beta}_{0} \mid \mathbf{S}\right]\right\}
\end{aligned}
$$

which is equal to 0 since $E[\mathbf{V} \mid \mathbf{S}]=\mathbf{0}$ and $E[U \mid \mathbf{X}, \mathbf{S}]=0$. This gives Assumption 3.1(d) from Chernozhukov et al. (2018) with $\lambda_{n}=0$.

Step 2. By definition,

$$
\begin{aligned}
J_{0} & =E\left[\psi^{a}\left(\mathbf{W} ; \eta_{0}\right)\right] \\
& =E\left[-\left(\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})\right)\left(\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})\right)^{T}\right] \\
& =E\left[-\mathbf{V} \mathbf{V}^{T}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

By assumption 1(c), the singular values of this matrix are between $c_{0}$ and $C$. This satisfies Assumption 3.1 (e) from Chernozhukov et al. (2018). Since the map $\eta \mapsto E\left[\psi\left(\mathbf{W} ; \boldsymbol{\beta}_{0}, \eta\right)\right]$ is twice Gateux-differentiable in $T$, this completes verification of Assumption 3.1 from Chernozhukov et al. (2018).

Step 3. Assumption 3.2(a) from Chernozhukov et al. (2018) holds by construction of $\mathcal{T}_{n}$ and Assumption 1(e). In addition, $\psi\left(\mathbf{W} ; \boldsymbol{\beta}_{0}, \eta_{0}\right)=U \mathbf{V}$, so the eigenvalues of the matrix

$$
E\left[\psi\left(\mathbf{W} ; \boldsymbol{\beta}_{0}, \eta_{0}\right) \psi\left(\mathbf{W} ; \boldsymbol{\beta}_{0}, \eta_{0}\right)^{T}\right]=E\left[U^{2} \mathbf{V} \mathbf{V}^{T}\right]
$$

are bounded below by $c_{0}$ by Assumption 1(c). This verifies Assumption 3.2(d) from Chernozhukov et al. (2018).

Step 4. Next, we verify Assumption 3.2(b) from Chernozhukov et al. (2018). For any

$\eta=(\ell, \mathbf{m}) \in \mathcal{T}_{n}$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
m_{n}^{\prime} & =E\left[\|\psi^{a}(\mathbf{S} ; \eta)\|^{q / 2}\right]^{2 / q} \\
& =\left\|\|(\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{m}(\mathbf{S}))(\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{m}(\mathbf{S}))^{T}\right\|\right\|_{P, q / 2} \\
& \leqslant\left\|\left\|\left(\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})\right)\left(\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})\right)^{T}\right\|+\left\|\left(\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})\right)\left(\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})-\mathbf{m}(\mathbf{S})\right)^{T}\right\|\right.\right. \\
& \left.+\left\|\left(\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})-\mathbf{m}(\mathbf{S})\right)\left(\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})\right)^{T}\right\|+\left\|\left(\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})-\mathbf{m}(\mathbf{S})\right)\left(\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})-\mathbf{m}(\mathbf{S})\right)^{T}\right\|\right\|_{P, q / 2} \\
& =\left\|\left\|\mathbf{V V}^{T}\right\|+2\left\|\mathbf{V}\left(\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})-\mathbf{m}(\mathbf{S})\right)^{T}\right\|+\left\|\left(\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})-\mathbf{m}(\mathbf{S})\right)\left(\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})-\mathbf{m}(\mathbf{S})\right)^{T}\right\|\right\|_{P, q / 2} \\
& \leqslant\left\|\left\|\mathbf{V V}^{T}\right\|\right\|_{P, q / 2}+2\left\|\left\|\mathbf{V}\left(\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})-\mathbf{m}(\mathbf{S})\right)^{T}\right\|\right\|_{P, q / 2}+\left\|\left\|\left(\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})-\mathbf{m}(\mathbf{S})\right)\left(\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})-\mathbf{m}(\mathbf{S})\right)^{T}\right\|\right\|_{P, q / 2} \\
& =\left\|\|\mathbf{V}\|^{2}\right\|_{P, q / 2}+2\left\|\|\mathbf{V}\| \times\left\|\left(\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})-\mathbf{m}(\mathbf{S})\right)\right\|\right\|_{P, q / 2}+\left\|\left\|\left(\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})-\mathbf{m}(\mathbf{S})\right)\right\|^{2}\right\|_{P, q / 2} \\
& \leqslant\|\|\mathbf{V}\|\|_{P, q}^{2}+2\|\|\mathbf{V}\|\|_{P, q} \times\left\|\left\|\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})-\mathbf{m}(\mathbf{S})\right\|\right\|_{P, q}+\left\|\left\|\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})-\mathbf{m}(\mathbf{S})\right\|\right\|_{P, q}^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

by the triangle inequality for the $\|\cdot\|$-norm, the triangle inequality for the $\|\cdot\|_{P, q / 2}$-norm, the fact that for vectors $\mathbf{u}$ and $\mathbf{v},\left\|\mathbf{u v}^{T}\right\|=\|\mathbf{u}\|\|\mathbf{v}\|$, and by the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality. Note that for a random vector $\mathbf{Z}$ with $p$ elements, if $\left\|Z_{j}\right\|_{P, q}<C$ for $j=1, \ldots, p$, then $\|\|\mathbf{Z}\|\|_{P, q} \leqslant\|\|\mathbf{Z}\|_{1}\|_{P, q} \leqslant\left\|Z_{1}\right\|_{P, q}+\ldots+\left\|Z_{p}\right\|_{P, q} \leqslant p C$, by the fact that $\|\mathbf{Z}\| \leqslant\|\mathbf{Z}\|_{1}$ and monotonicity of expectation, then the triangle inequality, then the assumption that $\left\|Z_{j}\right\|_{P, q}<$ $C$ for $j=1, \ldots, p$. By assumption $\left\|V_{1}\right\|_{P, q}+\ldots+\left\|V_{p}\right\|_{P, q} \leqslant C$. Also, for $\eta \in \mathcal{T}_{n},\left\|\eta_{0}-\eta\right\|_{P, q}<C$. Therefore we have that:

$$
\begin{aligned}
m_{n}^{\prime} & \leqslant\|\|\mathbf{V}\|\|_{P, q}^{2}+2\|\|\mathbf{V}\|\|_{P, q} \times\left\|\left\|\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})-\mathbf{m}(\mathbf{S})\right\|\right\|_{P, q}+\left\|\left\|\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})-\mathbf{m}(\mathbf{S})\right\|\right\|_{P, q}^{2} \\
& \leqslant(p C)^{2}+2(p C)(p C)+(p C)^{2}=4 p^{2} C^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

bounding $m_{n}^{\prime}$ as desired.
Next we address $m_{n}$. Note that by assumption, $\left\|\boldsymbol{\beta}_{0}\right\|<\sqrt{p} C$ since $\left\|\beta_{0}\right\|_{\infty}<C$. Note also

that $Y-\ell_{0}(\mathbf{S})=U+\mathbf{V}^{T} \boldsymbol{\beta}_{0}$.

$$
\begin{aligned}
& m_{n}=\left(E\left[\|\psi\left(\mathbf{W} ; \boldsymbol{\beta}_{0}, \eta\right)\right]^{q / 2}\right]^{2 / q} \\
& =\left\|\psi\left(\mathbf{W} ; \boldsymbol{\beta}_{0}, \eta\right)\right\|_{P, q / 2} \\
& =\|\|U \mathbf{V}+U\left(\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})-\mathbf{m}(\mathbf{S})\right)+\left(\ell_{0}(\mathbf{S})-\ell(\mathbf{S})\right) \mathbf{V} \\
& +\left(\ell_{0}(\mathbf{S})-\ell(\mathbf{S})\right)\left(\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})-\mathbf{m}(\mathbf{S})\right) \\
& -\left(\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})-\mathbf{m}(\mathbf{S})\right)^{T} \boldsymbol{\beta}_{0} \mathbf{V}-\left(\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})-\mathbf{m}(\mathbf{S})\right)\left(\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})-\mathbf{m}(\mathbf{S})\right)^{T} \boldsymbol{\beta}_{0}\| \|_{P, q / 2} \\
& \leqslant\|\|U \mathbf{V}\|+\| U\left(\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})-\mathbf{m}(\mathbf{S})\right)\|+\|\left(\ell_{0}(\mathbf{S})-\ell(\mathbf{S})\right) \mathbf{V}\|+\|\left(\ell_{0}(\mathbf{S})-\ell(\mathbf{S})\right)\left(\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})-\mathbf{m}(\mathbf{S})\right) \| \\
& +\left\|\left(\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})-\mathbf{m}(\mathbf{S})\right)^{T} \boldsymbol{\beta}_{0} \mathbf{V}\right\|+\left\|\left(\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})-\mathbf{m}(\mathbf{S})\right)\left(\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})-\mathbf{m}(\mathbf{S})\right)^{T} \boldsymbol{\beta}_{0}\right\| \|_{P, q / 2} \\
& \leqslant\|\|U \mathbf{V}\| \|_{P, q / 2}+\|\left\|U\left(\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})-\mathbf{m}(\mathbf{S})\right)\right\| \|_{P, q / 2}+\|\|\left(\ell_{0}(\mathbf{S})-\ell(\mathbf{S})\right) \mathbf{V}\| \|_{P, q / 2} \\
& +\|\|\left(\ell_{0}(\mathbf{S})-\ell(\mathbf{S})\right)\left(\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})-\mathbf{m}(\mathbf{S})\right)\| \|_{P, q / 2} \\
& +\left\|\mathbf{V}\left(\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})-\mathbf{m}(\mathbf{S})\right)^{T} \boldsymbol{\beta}_{0}\right\| \|_{P, q / 2}+\|\left\|\left(\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})-\mathbf{m}(\mathbf{S})\right)\left(\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})-\mathbf{m}(\mathbf{S})\right)^{T} \boldsymbol{\beta}_{0}\right\| \|_{P, q / 2} \\
& \leqslant\|U\|_{P, q}\|\|\mathbf{V}\| \|_{P, q}+\|U\|_{P, q}\left\|\left\|\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})-\mathbf{m}(\mathbf{S})\right\|\right\|_{P, q}+\left\|\ell_{0}(\mathbf{S})-\ell(\mathbf{S})\right\|_{P, q}\|\|\mathbf{V}\| \|_{P, q} \\
& +\left\|\ell_{0}(\mathbf{S})-\ell(\mathbf{S})\right\|_{P, q}\left\|\left\|\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})-\mathbf{m}(\mathbf{S})\right\|\right\|_{P, q} \\
& +\|\|\mathbf{V}\| \|_{P, q}\left\|\left\|\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})-\mathbf{m}(\mathbf{S})\right\|\right\|_{P, q}\left\|\boldsymbol{\beta}_{0}\right\|+\left\|\left\|\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})-\mathbf{m}(\mathbf{S})\right\|\right\|_{P, q}^{2}\left\|\boldsymbol{\beta}_{0}\right\| \\
& \leqslant p C^{2}+p C^{2}+p C^{2}+p C^{2}+p^{2} C^{3}+p^{2} C^{3} \\
& =4 p C^{2}+2 p^{2} C^{3},
\end{aligned}
$$

bounding $m_{n}$ as desired. The first two inequalities are due to the triangle inequality; the third inequality due to Cauchy-Schwartz; and the final inequality by assumed bounds on the quantities in the previous step and the bounds established in the derivation of the bound on $m_{n}^{\prime}$ above.

Step 5. Finally, we verify the conditions of Assumption 3.2(c) from Chernozhukov et al. (2018). Starting with $r_{n}=\sup _{\eta \in \mathcal{T}_{n}}\left\|E\left[\psi^{a}(\mathbf{W} ; \eta)\right]-E\left[\psi^{a}\left(\mathbf{W} ; \eta_{0}\right)\right]\right\|$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left\|E\left[\psi^{a}(\mathbf{W} ; \eta)\right]-E\left[\psi^{a}\left(\mathbf{W} ; \eta_{0}\right)\right]\right\|=\| E\left[\psi^{a}(\mathbf{W} ; \eta)-\psi^{a}\left(\mathbf{W} ; \eta_{0}\right)\right]\| \\
& =\| E\left[-(\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{m}(S))(\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{m}(S))^{T}+\mathbf{V V}^{T}\right]\| \\
& \leqslant\| E\left[\mathbf{V}\left(\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})-\mathbf{m}(\mathbf{S}))^{T}\right]\right\|+\| E\left[\left(\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})-\mathbf{m}(\mathbf{S})\right) \mathbf{V}^{T}\right]\| \\
& +\| E\left[\left(\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})-\mathbf{m}(\mathbf{S})\right)\left(\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})-\mathbf{m}(\mathbf{S})\right)^{T}\right]\| \\
& \leqslant 2 E\left[\|\mathbf{V}\| \cdot\left\|\left(\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})-\mathbf{m}(\mathbf{S})\right)\right\|\right]+E\left[\left\|\left(\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})-\mathbf{m}(\mathbf{S})\right)\right\|^{2}\right] \\
& \leqslant 2 \sqrt{E\left[\|\mathbf{V}\|^{2}\right]} E\left[\left\|\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})-\mathbf{m}(\mathbf{S})\right\|^{2}\right]+E\left[\left\|\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})-\mathbf{m}(\mathbf{S})\right\|^{2}\right] \\
& =2\|\|\mathbf{V}\|\|_{P, 2} \cdot\left\|\left\|\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})-\mathbf{m}(\mathbf{S})\right\|\right\|_{P, 2}+\left\|\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})-\mathbf{m}(\mathbf{S})\right\|\|_{P, 2}^{2} \\
& \leqslant(p C)\left(p \delta_{n}\right)+\left(p^{2} C \delta_{n}\right) \\
& \leqslant \delta_{n}^{\prime}
\end{aligned}
$$

Where the first inequality is by the triangle inequality, the second inequality is by Jensen's inequality, the third inequality is by Cauchy-Schwarz, and the following inequality by the assumption that $\left\|V_{j}\right\|_{P, 2}<C$ and $\left\|m_{0 j}-m_{j}\right\|_{P, 2} \leqslant \delta_{n}$ and $\left\|m_{0 j}-m_{j}\right\|_{P, q} \leqslant C$ for $\eta \in \mathcal{T}_{n}$ for $j=1, \ldots, p$ and $q>4$ (since $\|f\|_{P, q_{1}} \leqslant\|f\|_{P, q_{2}}$ for $0<q_{1}<q_{2}<\infty$ by Jensen's inequality with $\phi(x)=|x|^{q_{2} / q_{1}}$ ). This establishes the bound on $r_{n}$.

Next we establish the bound on $r_{n}^{\prime}=\sup _{\eta \in \mathcal{T}_{n}}\left(E\left[\left\|\psi\left(\mathbf{W} ; \boldsymbol{\beta}_{0}, \eta\right)-\psi\left(\mathbf{W} ; \boldsymbol{\beta}_{0}, \eta_{0}\right)\right\|^{2}\right]\right)^{1 / 2}$ :

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(E\left[\|\psi\left(\mathbf{W} ; \boldsymbol{\beta}_{0}, \eta\right)-\psi\left(\mathbf{W} ; \boldsymbol{\beta}_{0}, \eta_{0}\right)\right]^{2}\right]\right)^{1 / 2}= & \left\|\psi\left(\mathbf{W} ; \boldsymbol{\beta}_{0}, \eta\right)-\psi\left(\mathbf{W} ; \boldsymbol{\beta}_{0}, \eta_{0}\right)\right\|_{P, 2} \\
= & \left\|\left|\left\{Y-\ell(\mathbf{S})-(\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{m}(\mathbf{S}))^{T} \boldsymbol{\beta}_{0}\right\}(\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{m}(\mathbf{S}))-\right.\right. \\
& \left.\left.\left\{Y-\ell_{0}(\mathbf{S})-\left(\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})\right)^{T} \boldsymbol{\beta}_{0}\right\}\left(\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})\right)\right\|\right\|_{P, 2} \\
\leqslant & \left\|\left\|U\left(\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})-\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})\right)\right\|+\left\|\left(\ell_{0}(\mathbf{S})-\ell(\mathbf{S})\right) \mathbf{V}\right\|\right. \\
& \left.+\left\|\left(\ell_{0}(\mathbf{S})-\ell(\mathbf{S})\right)\left(\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})-\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})\right)\right\|\right. \\
& +\left\|\mathbf{V}\left(\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})-\mathbf{m}(\mathbf{S})\right)^{T} \boldsymbol{\beta}_{0}\right\| \\
& \left.+\left\|\left(\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})-\mathbf{m}(\mathbf{S})\right)\left(\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})-\mathbf{m}(\mathbf{S})\right)^{T} \boldsymbol{\beta}_{0}\right\|\right\|_{P, 2} \\
\leqslant & \left\||U| \cdot\left\|\left(\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})-\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})\right)\right\|\right\|_{P, 2}+\left\|\left|\ell_{0}(\mathbf{S})-\ell(\mathbf{S})\right| \cdot\|\mathbf{V}\|\right\|_{P, 2} \\
& +\left\|\left|\ell_{0}(\mathbf{S})-\ell(\mathbf{S})\right| \cdot\left\|\left(\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})-\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})\right)\right\|\right\|_{P, 2} \\
& +\left\|\left\|\mathbf{V}\left(\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})-\mathbf{m}(\mathbf{S})\right)^{T} \boldsymbol{\beta}_{0}\right\|\right\|_{P, 2} \\
& +\left\|\left\|\left(\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})-\mathbf{m}(\mathbf{S})\right)\left(\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})-\mathbf{m}(\mathbf{S})\right)^{T} \boldsymbol{\beta}_{0}\right\|\right\|_{P, 2} \\
\leqslant & \left\||U| \cdot\left\|\left(\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})-\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})\right)\right\|\right\|_{P, 2}+\left\|\left|\ell_{0}(\mathbf{S})-\ell(\mathbf{S})\right| \cdot\|\mathbf{V}\|\right\|_{P, 2} \\
& +\left\|\left|\ell_{0}(\mathbf{S})-\ell(\mathbf{S})\right| \cdot\left\|\left(\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})-\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})\right)\right\|\right\|_{P, 2} \\
& +\left\|\left\|\mathbf{V}\right\| \cdot\left\|\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})-\mathbf{m}(\mathbf{S})\right\|\right\|_{P, 2}\left\|\boldsymbol{\beta}_{0}\right\|\right. \\
& \left.+\left\|\left\|\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})-\mathbf{m}(\mathbf{S})\right\|^{2}\right\|_{P, 2}\left\|\boldsymbol{\beta}_{0}\right\|\right. \\
\leqslant & \sqrt{C} p \delta_{n}+\sqrt{p C} \delta_{n}+p C \delta_{n}+\sqrt{p C} p \delta_{n} C+\sqrt{p} C p \delta_{n} C \\
= & (\sqrt{C} p+\sqrt{p C}+p C+\sqrt{p C} p C+\sqrt{p} C^{2} p) \delta_{n} \\
\leqslant & \delta_{n}^{\prime}
\end{aligned}
$$

as desired, where the final inequality is due to the assumptions that $\left\|E\left[U^{2} \mid \mathbf{S}\right]\right\|_{P, \infty} \leqslant C$, $\left\|E\left[V_{j}^{2} \mid \mathbf{S}\right]\right\|_{P, \infty} \leqslant C$ for $j=1, \ldots, p$, and $\left\|\eta_{0}-\eta\right\|_{P, \infty} \leqslant C$ for $\eta \in \mathcal{T}_{n}$, and applying the law of iterated expectation.

Finally we check the condition that $\lambda_{n}^{\prime}=\sup _{r \in(0,1), \eta \in \mathcal{T}_{n}}\left\|\partial_{r}^{2} E\left[\psi\left(\mathbf{W} ; \boldsymbol{\beta}_{0}, \eta_{0}+r\left(\eta-\eta_{0}\right)\right)\right]\right\| \leqslant$

$\delta_{n}^{\prime} / \sqrt{n}$. Define $f(r):=E\left[\psi\left(\mathbf{W} ; \boldsymbol{\beta}_{0}, \eta_{0}+r\left(\eta-\eta_{0}\right)\right], r \in(0,1)\right.$. Then for $r \in(0,1)$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\delta_{r}^{2} f(r) & =E\left[2\left(\ell(\mathbf{S})-\ell_{0}(\mathbf{S})\right) \times\left(\mathbf{m}(\mathbf{S})-\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})\right)-2\left(\mathbf{m}(\mathbf{S})-\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})\right)\left(\mathbf{m}(\mathbf{S})-\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})\right)^{T} \boldsymbol{\beta}_{0}\right] \\
& =2 E\left[\left(\ell(\mathbf{S})-\ell_{0}(\mathbf{S})\right) \times\left(\mathbf{m}(\mathbf{S})-\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})\right)\right]-2 E\left[\left(\mathbf{m}(\mathbf{S})-\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})\right)\left(\mathbf{m}(\mathbf{S})-\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})\right)^{T} \boldsymbol{\beta}_{0}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

Then note that:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\|E\left[\left(\ell(\mathbf{S})-\ell_{0}(\mathbf{S})\right) \times\left(\mathbf{m}(\mathbf{S})-\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})\right)\right]\right\| & =\sqrt{\sum_{j=1}^{p} E\left[\left(\ell(\mathbf{S})-\ell_{0}(\mathbf{S})\right) \times\left(m_{j}(\mathbf{S})-m_{0 j}(\mathbf{S})\right)\right]^{2}} \\
& \leqslant \sqrt{\sum_{j=1}^{p} E\left[\left(\ell(\mathbf{S})-\ell_{0}(\mathbf{S})\right)^{2}\right] \times E\left[\left(m_{j}(\mathbf{S})-m_{0 j}(\mathbf{S})\right)^{2}\right]} \\
& =\sqrt{\sum_{j=1}^{p}\left\|\ell-\ell_{0}\right\|_{P, 2}^{2} \times\left\|m_{j}-m_{0 j}\right\|_{P, 2}^{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

For $\eta \in T,\left\|\ell-\ell_{0}\right\|_{P, 2}^{2} \times\left\|m_{j}-m_{0 j}\right\|_{P, 2}^{2} \leqslant \delta_{n}^{2} n^{-1}$, so:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\|E\left[\left(\ell(\mathbf{S})-\ell_{0}(\mathbf{S})\right) \times\left(\mathbf{m}(\mathbf{S})-\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})\right)\right]\right\| & \leqslant \sqrt{\sum_{j=1}^{p} \delta_{n}^{2} n^{-1}} \\
& =\sqrt{p \delta_{n}^{2} n^{-1}} \\
& =\sqrt{p} \delta_{n} n^{-1 / 2}
\end{aligned}
$$

By the same reasoning, $\left\|E\left[\left(\mathbf{m}(\mathbf{S})-\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})\right)^{2}\right]\right\| \leqslant \sqrt{p} \delta_{n} n^{-1 / 2}$. Then, we have that $\| \partial_{r}^{2} E\left[\psi\left(\mathbf{W} ; \boldsymbol{\beta}_{0}, \eta_{0}+\right.\right.$ $\left.\left.r\left(\eta-\eta_{0}\right)\right)\right]\|=\| 2 E\left[\left(\ell(\mathbf{S})-\ell_{0}(\mathbf{S})\right) \times\left(\mathbf{m}(\mathbf{S})-\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})\right)\right]-2 E\left[\left(\mathbf{m}(\mathbf{S})-\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})\right)\left(\mathbf{m}(\mathbf{S})-\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})\right)^{T} \boldsymbol{\beta}_{0}\right]\| \leqslant$ $\left.2\left\|E\left[\left(\ell(\mathbf{S})-\ell_{0}(\mathbf{S})\right) \times\left(\mathbf{m}(\mathbf{S})-\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})\right)\right]\right\|+2\left\|E\left[\left(\mathbf{m}(\mathbf{S})-\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})\right)\left(\mathbf{m}(\mathbf{S})-\mathbf{m}_{0}(\mathbf{S})\right)^{T} \boldsymbol{\beta}_{0}\right]\right\|\right.$, which does not depend on $r$, so that for $\eta \in T,\left\|\partial_{r}^{2} E\left[\psi\left(\mathbf{W} ; \boldsymbol{\beta}_{0}, \eta_{0}+r\left(\eta-\eta_{0}\right)\right)\right]\right\| \leqslant 4 \sqrt{p} \delta_{n} n^{-1 / 2} \leqslant$ $\delta_{n}^{\prime} n^{-1 / 2}$, establishing the desired bound on $\lambda_{n}^{\prime}$.

With the conditions of Assumptions 3.1 and 3.2 from Chernozhukov et al. (2018) verified, Lemma 1 follows from Facts 3.1 and 3.2 from Chernozhukov et al. (2018).

Lemma 2 follows directly from Theorem 3.3 from (Eberts and Steinwart, 2013), using $\rho=\ln (n)$. Note that the estimated function from the least-squares SVM with Gaussian kernel and least-squares loss analyzed in (Eberts and Steinwart, 2013) is identical to the posterior mean of a Gaussian process with Gaussian kernel; see e.g. (Kanagawa et al., 2018).

Lemma 2 (Convergence rate for bounded regression using GP posterior mean): Let $\widehat{f}$ be an estimate of $f(S)=E(Y \mid S)$ obtained by a Gaussian process posterior mean, with Gaussian kernel, using parameters $\gamma_{n}, \lambda_{n}$ selected by the training-validation scheme in (Eberts and Steinwart, 2013) using grids as specified in Algorithm 1. Let $P_{S}$ be the marginal distribution of $S$ over $\mathbb{R}^{d}$ with support in the $\|\cdot\|_{2}$-unit ball. Let the density of $P_{S}$ be $p_{S} \in L_{q}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d}\right)$ for some $q \geqslant 1$, and let $f \in L_{2}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d}\right) \cap L_{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d}\right)$ and $f \in B_{2 s, \infty}^{\alpha}$ for $\alpha \geqslant 1$ and $s \geqslant 1$ such that $\frac{1}{q}+\frac{1}{s}=1$. Let $Y \in[-M, M], M>0$ and let $\widehat{f}$ be clipped at $-M, M$.

Then with probability no less than $1-\frac{1}{n},\|\widehat{f}-f\|_{P, 2} \leqslant C \log (n) n^{-\frac{\alpha}{2 \alpha+d}+\xi}$, for all $\xi>0$ and some $C>0$.

Lemma 3 follows directly from Theorem 3.6 from (Eberts and Steinwart, 2013), using $\widehat{\rho}=\ln (n)$ and $\bar{\rho}=\ln (n)$ and clipping the absolute value of the fitted function at $\min \left\{1, M_{n}\right\}$ rather than simply $M_{n}$, which does not change the result since by assumption the true function lies in $[-1,1]$. Note that per the proof of Theorem 3.6, the constant $C$ in the original statement of Theorem 3.6 does not depend on either $\widehat{\rho}$ or $\bar{\rho}$ allowing these substitutions.

Lemma 3 (Convergence rate for regression with normal errors using GP posterior mean): Let $\widehat{f}$ be an estimate of $f(S)=E(Y \mid S)$ obtained by a Gaussian process posterior mean, with Gaussian kernel, using parameters $\gamma_{n}, \lambda_{n}$ selected by the training-validation scheme in (Eberts and Steinwart, 2013) using grids as specified in Algorithm 1. Let $P_{S}$ be the marginal distribution of $S$ over $\mathbb{R}^{d}$ with support in the $\|\cdot\|_{2}$-unit ball. Let the density of $P_{S}$ be $p_{S} \in L_{q}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d}\right)$ for some $q \geqslant 1$, and let $f \in L_{2}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d}\right) \cap L_{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d}\right)$ and $f \in B_{2 s, \infty}^{\alpha}$ for $\alpha \geqslant 1$ and $s \geqslant 1$ such that $\frac{1}{q}+\frac{1}{s}=1$. Assume further that $f(S) \in[-1,1]$.

Let $Y_{i}=f\left(S_{i}\right)+\epsilon_{i}$ where $\epsilon_{i} \sim$ ind. $N\left(0, \sigma_{i}^{2}\right)$, and let there exist some constant $C_{0}$ such that all $\sigma_{i}^{2}<C_{0}$. Let $\widehat{f}$ be clipped so that $|\widehat{f}| \leqslant \min \left\{1, M_{n}\right\}$ where $M_{n}=4 \sqrt{C_{0}} \sqrt{\ln (n)}$.

Then with probability no less than $1-\frac{2}{n},\|\widehat{f}-f\|_{P, 2} \leqslant C \log (n) n^{-\frac{\alpha}{2 \alpha+d}+\xi}$, for all $\xi>0$ and some $C>0$.

The proof of Theorem 1 follows by verifying the Assumption 1 using assumptions A1-A6 and Facts 1-3.

Proof. [Proof of Theorem 1] First note that estimation of $\boldsymbol{\beta}_{0}$ by $\widehat{\boldsymbol{\beta}}_{D S R}$ using Algorithm 1 is equivalent to using DML2 in Definition 3.2 of Chernozhukov et al. (2018), under the Partially Linear Regression DML estimation established by Lemma 1, and estimation of the nuisance parameters uses the same Gaussian Process (GP) estimates used in Facts 2 and 3. Therefore, the result of Theorem 1 follows from satisfying Assumption 1, which in turn is achieved in part by satisfying the assumptions for Facts 2 and 3 which establish the necessary convergence rates for prediction using GP regression.

In Assumption 1, (a) follows by Assumption A1, (b) follows from the assumption of bounded or normal distributions of $U, V_{j}$, so that all moments are finite, and the assumption that $\boldsymbol{\beta}_{0} \in \mathbb{R}^{p}$, and (c) and (d) follow from Assumption A2.

To satisfy (e) in Assumption 1, first note that by Assumption A4 the components of $\eta_{0}$ are bounded in some interval, and that the nuisance parameter estimates are clipped accordingly to reside in some interval, satisfying $\left\|\eta_{0}-\widehat{\eta}_{0}\right\|_{P, \infty}<C$ for some $C>0$ (recall the notation $\left\|\eta_{0}-\widehat{\eta}_{0}\right\|_{P, q}=\max _{j}\left\|\eta_{0 j}-\widehat{\eta}_{0 j}\right\|_{P, q}$ for $\left.q \in[0, \infty)\right)$. Next apply Lemmas 2 and 3 to satisfy the convergence rate requirements. Let $\alpha_{X} \geqslant \frac{d}{2}$ and $\alpha_{X}>1$ per Assumption A6. Then if each $m_{j 0}$ is estimated by $\widehat{m}_{j 0}$ using a Gaussian process mean with clipping at appropriate bounds as in Facts 2 and 3, then with probability no less than $1-\frac{2}{n},\left\|\widehat{m}_{j 0}-m_{j 0}\right\|_{P, 2} \leqslant C_{j} \log (n) n^{-\frac{\alpha_{X}}{2 \alpha_{X}+d}+\xi}$ for any $\xi>0$ and some $C_{j}>0$, and $n^{-\frac{\alpha_{X}}{2 \alpha_{X}+d}}<n^{-1 / 4}$. Let $\gamma=\frac{\alpha_{X}}{2 \alpha_{X}+d}-1 / 4>0$. Then with probability no less than $1-\frac{2}{n},\left\|\widehat{m}_{j 0}-m_{j 0}\right\|_{P, 2} \leqslant C_{j} \log (n) n^{-1 / 4} n^{-\gamma} n^{\xi}$, for all $\xi>0$. Pick $\xi<\gamma$. Let $\gamma^{*}=\gamma-\xi>0$. This holds for $j=1, \ldots, p$; let $C_{m}$ be greater than or equal to all $C_{j}$. Then letting $\delta_{n}^{\prime}=C_{m}\left(\log (n) n^{-\gamma^{*}}\right) \vee n^{-1 / 4} \rightarrow 0$, we have that $\left\|\widehat{m}_{j 0}-m_{j 0}\right\|_{P, 2} \leqslant \delta_{n}^{\prime} n^{-1 / 4}$ with probability no less than $1-\frac{2}{n}$ for all $m_{0 j}, j=1, \ldots, p$, and if $\alpha_{Y} \geqslant \frac{d}{2}$ and $\alpha_{Y}>\frac{d^{2}}{4 \alpha_{X}}$, the analogous result holds for $g_{0}$ as well.

Since all of the errors (of estimates of $g_{0}, m_{01}, \ldots, m_{0 p}$ ) individually obey the desired rates, each with marginal probability no less than $1-\frac{2}{n}$, there exists a sequence $\Delta \rightarrow 0$ such that with probability no less than $1-\Delta_{n}$, all estimates of $g_{0}, m_{01}, \ldots, m_{0 p}$ simultaneously obey the desired error bounds. To see why, let $A_{k n}, k=1, \ldots, K, n=1,2, \ldots$ be a finite number $K$ of sequences of events, such that $P\left(A_{k n}\right) \rightarrow 1$ as $n \rightarrow \infty$ for each $k . P\left(A_{1 n} \cup A_{2 n}\right)=P\left(A_{1 n}\right)+$ $P\left(A_{2 n}\right)-P\left(A_{1 n} \cap A_{2 n}\right)$, and since $P\left(A_{1 n} \cup A_{2 n}\right) \geqslant P\left(A_{1 n}\right), P\left(A_{2 n}\right)$, we have that $P\left(A_{1 n} \cup\right.$ $\left.A_{2 n}\right) \rightarrow 1$ as $n \rightarrow \infty$. Hence, $\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} P\left(A_{1 n} \cap A_{2 n}\right)=\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} P\left(A_{1 n}\right)+\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} P\left(A_{2 n}\right)-$ $\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} P\left(A_{1 n} \cup A_{2 n}\right)=1$. Applying induction establishes that $\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} P\left(A_{1 n} \cap A_{2 n} \cap \ldots \cap\right.$ $\left.A_{K n}\right)=1$. Therefore, there exists some sequence $L_{n} \rightarrow 0$ such that $P\left(A_{1 n} \cap A_{2 n} \cap \ldots \cap A_{K n}\right) \geqslant$ $1-L_{n}$.

Therefore, there exists some sequence $\Delta_{n} \rightarrow 0$ such that $\left\|\widehat{g}_{0}-g_{0}\right\|_{P, 2} \times\left\|\widehat{m}_{0 j}-m_{0 j}\right\|_{P, 2} \leqslant$ $C \delta_{n} n^{-\frac{1}{2}},\left\|\widehat{m}_{0 j}-m_{0 j}\right\|_{P, 2}^{2} \leqslant C \delta_{n} n^{-\frac{1}{2}}$, and $\left\|\widehat{\eta}_{0}-\eta_{0}\right\|_{P, 2} \leqslant \delta_{n}$ for $j=1, \ldots, p$, with $\delta_{n}=\delta_{n}^{\prime 2} \geqslant n^{-1 / 2}$, with probability no less than $1-\Delta_{n}$.

Thus part (e) of Assumption 1 is satisfied.
With parts (a)-(e) of Assumption 1 satisfied, apply Lemma 1 to obtain $\widehat{\operatorname{Var}}\left(\widehat{\boldsymbol{\beta}}_{0}\right)^{-1 / 2}\left(\widehat{\boldsymbol{\beta}}_{0}-\right.$ $\left.\boldsymbol{\beta}_{0}\right) \xrightarrow{D} N\left(\mathbf{0}, \mathbf{I}_{p}\right)$.

abstract:
Public health data are often spatially dependent, but standard spatial
regression methods can suffer from bias and invalid inference when the
independent variable is associated with spatially-correlated residuals. This
could occur if, for example, there is an unmeasured environmental contaminant
associated with the independent and outcome variables in a spatial regression
analysis. Geoadditive structural equation modeling (gSEM), in which an
estimated spatial trend is removed from both the explanatory and response
variables before estimating the parameters of interest, has previously been
proposed as a solution, but there has been little investigation of gSEM's
properties with point-referenced data. We link gSEM to results on double
machine learning and semiparametric regression based on two-stage procedures.
We propose using these semiparametric estimators for spatial regression using
Gaussian processes with Mat\`ern covariance to estimate the spatial trends, and
term this class of estimators Double Spatial Regression (DSR). We derive
regularity conditions for root-$n$ asymptotic normality and consistency and
closed-form variance estimation, and show that in simulations where standard
spatial regression estimators are highly biased and have poor coverage, DSR can
mitigate bias more effectively than competitors and obtain nominal coverage.
